info.title: Setting up a UEFI HTTP Boot server

section.title: Environment
section.para: This document applies to the following product and product versions:

section.title: Introduction
section.para: HTTP Boot can remotely install operating systems from an HTTP URL. While PXE can only deploy images to servers in a local subnet, HTTP Boot can deploy images to servers across different subnets in routed networks, and can quickly transfer larger files, such as the Linux kernel and root file system.
This article shows you how to configure DNS, DHCP, and HTTP on a single machine to act as an HTTP Boot server.

listitem.para: &sles; is installed and up to date on your server.
Networking is configured on your server.
You have a &sles; ISO image available, either on a media drive or downloaded on your server.
If you want to enable SSL support, you must have an SSL certificate installed on your server.

note.para: Because of a change in UEFI 2.7, we recommend using a shim boot loader from &sle; 15 or newer to avoid potential errors caused by the additional DNS node.

step.para: Install the apache2 package:
In the root directory of the HTTP Boot server (/srv/www/htdocs/), create a subdirectory for the installation content. For example, /srv/www/htdocs/sle/:
Copy or extract all of the files from the ISO to the new directory.
To configure the boot menu, edit the /srv/www/htdocs/sle/EFI/BOOT/grub.cfg file using the following example as a reference:
step.screen:
menuentry 'Installation IPv4' --class opensuse --class gnu-linux --class gnu --class os { set gfxpayload=keep echo 'Loading kernel ...' linuxefi /sle/boot/x86_64/loader/linux install=http://www.httpboot.local/sle echo 'Loading initial ramdisk ...' initrdefi /sle/boot/x86_64/loader/initrd }
menuentry 'Installation IPv6' --class opensuse --class gnu-linux --class gnu --class os { set gfxpayload=keep echo 'Loading kernel ...' linuxefi /sle/boot/x86_64/loader/linux install=http://www.httpboot.local/sle ipv6only=1 ifcfg=*=dhcp6,DHCLIENT6_MODE=managed echo 'Loading initial ramdisk ...' initrdefi /sle/boot/x86_64/loader/initrd }

section.para: In this procedure, replace the example IP addresses and subnets with the appropriate values for your system.

callout.para: The vendor class ID must be HTTPClient. The client uses this ID to identify an HTTP Boot offer.
The boot URL must point to the directory you created in .

step.para: To set up the DHCPv6 server, edit the /etc/dhcpd6.conf file to add the following configuration:

callout.para: The boot URL must point to the directory you created in .

The vendor class option must consist of the enterprise number, the vendor class length, and the vendor class content. The HTTP Boot driver ignores the enterprise number, so you can set it to 0. The vendor class length must 10, and the content must be HTTPClient. The client uses this ID to identify an HTTP Boot offer.

step.para: Start the DHCP servers:
step.screen: &prompt.user;sudo systemctl enable --now dhcpd &prompt.user;sudo systemctl enable --now dhcpd6

section.title: Enabling SSL support for the HTTP server (optional)
section.para: HTTPS Boot is only supported on &sle; 15 and newer. To use HTTPS Boot, you must convert an SSL certificate into the DER format and enroll it into the client's firmware.
This procedure assumes that you already have an SSL certificate installed on your server.

step.para: Convert the certificate into the DER format:

Enroll the server certificate into the client firmware. The procedure for enrolling the converted certificate depends on the client. For some hardware, you must enroll the certificate manually using an external storage device with the certificate on it. For machines with Redfish support, you can enroll the certificate remotely. Consult the documentation for your specific client for more information on enrolling certificates.
Edit the /etc/sysconfig/apache2 file to add the SSL flag:
In the same file, ensure that the ssl module appears in the APACHE_MODULES list:
step.screen: &prompt.user;sudo grep 'APACHE_MODULES.*ssl' /etc/sysconfig/apache2 APACHE_MODULES="actions alias auth_basic authn_core authn_file authz_host authz_groupfile authz_core authz_user autoindex cgi dir env expires include log_config mime negotiation setenvif ssl socache_shmcb userdir reqtimeout"

step.para: Copy the private key and the certificate to the /etc/apache2/ directory:
step.screen: &prompt.user;sudo cp server.key /etc/apache2/ssl.key/ &prompt.user;sudo chown wwwrun /etc/apache2/ssl.key/server.key &prompt.user;sudo chmod 600 /etc/apache2/ssl.key/server.key &prompt.user;sudo cp server.crt /etc/apache2/ssl.crt/

section.title: Summary
section.para: You can now use this server to remotely install operating systems from an HTTP URL, if the client firmware supports HTTP Boot. Consult the relevant documentation for information on how to enable HTTP Boot on client machines.
